It is intended solely to help you to come up with a rough hardware estimate required for Demantra software implementation.   Disclaimer: This document in any form, software or printed matter, contains proprietary information that is the exclusive property of Oracle. The analysis represents a estimate based on generally observed performance and research. Estimate results are not to be adopted as a guarantee, but as one input from the system to be validated by a robust testing program .    <Course name>   <Lesson number> - 2
data.text:
Presentation on theme: "Demantra Hardware Sizing & Calculations"— Presentation transcript:

1 Demantra Hardware Sizing & Calculations

Oracle VCP PMO May, 2013

2 <Course name> <Lesson number> - 2

Purpose: This document provides an overview of Oracle Demantra modules, Technical Architecture, Supported Hardware Stacks, Hardware Sizing Tool, Sizing inputs used in hardware sizing. It is intended solely to help you to come up with a rough hardware estimate required for Demantra software implementation. Disclaimer: This document in any form, software or printed matter, contains proprietary information that is the exclusive property of Oracle. Your access to and use of this confidential material is subject to the terms and conditions of your Oracle Software License and Service Agreement, which has been executed and with which you agree to comply. This document and information contained herein may not be disclosed, copied, reproduced or distributed to anyone outside Oracle without prior written consent of Oracle. This document is not part of your license agreement nor can it be incorporated into any contractual agreement with Oracle or its subsidiaries or affiliates. This document is for informational purposes only and is intended solely to assist you in planning for the hardware required for Demantra software implementation and Oracle is not responsible for the inaccuracies caused by data or by the tool to come up with the estimates. The analysis represents a estimate based on generally observed performance and research. Estimate results are not to be adopted as a guarantee, but as one input from the system to be validated by a robust testing program . <Course name> <Lesson number> - 2

3 Agenda Oracle Demantra Applications

Oracle Demantra Technical Architecture Oracle Demantra Product Components Supported Stacks Sizing Tool Overview Explanation of Sizing Inputs Other Hardware Requirements Sizing Request Process

4 Oracle Demantra Applications

Real-time Sales and Operations Planning Demand Management (DM) (Includes CTO & SPF) Advanced Forecasting & Demand Management (AFDM) Oracle Demantra Applications The following applications are available within the Demantra Spectrum suite: Demand Management Statistical forecasting Causal factors New product introduction Attribute based forecasting Editing, reporting, analysis, collaboration, events, and exceptions Advanced Forecasting and Demand Modeling Compute and display individual causal contribution and cross-correlations Promotion effectiveness engine Base and lift decomposition Real-time Sales and Operations Planning Sales and Operations Planning worksheets and workflows Balance supply and demand Synchronize marketing and supply chain on promotion plan Assimilate sales, finance, and operations into a cohesive planning process Deduction and Settlement Management Reconcile deductions and payments with proof of performance from your customer (retailer) per promotion terms Deduction and Settlement Management workflows, worksheets and processes Trade Promotion Optimization Suggest optimum set of promotions to maximize return on investment Trade Promotion Optimization engine, workflows and worksheets Predictive Trade Planning Define promotions Compute and display lifts, halo and cannibalization effects and promotion effectiveness Scenario evaluation against profitability, quota, and allocated budget, event management Predictive Trade Planning worksheets Instructor Notes Refer to Guided Demo Using Demantra Spectrum [LAB3A20Y] Predictive Trade Planning (PTP) Deduction and Settlement Management (DSM) Trade Promotion Optimization (TPO)

5 Oracle Demantra Application Cont’d

Oracle Demantra Engineered System Oracle In Memory Consumption Driven Planning (CDP) Optimized for X3 database and Exa Logic middle and engine tier Works only with Exa Hardware Oracle Demantra Version: Manage Downstream Data Manage Channel Forecast Manage Product and Store Lifecycle Manage Consensus Demand Plan Manage Replenishments 2 3 4 5 1 Oracle Apps Engineered System Daily Store Level Consumption Data Consumption Data to Replenishment Sell-Through and Sell-In Forecasting Safety Stock and Inventory Calculation Replenishment Order Generation Unified Solution for End-to-End Process Oracle In Memory Consumption Driven Planning a.k.a. CDP

6 Demantra Admin Utilities

Oracle In Memory Consumption Driven Planning/CDP Technical Architecture Demantra Admin Utilities

7 Oracle Demantra Technical Architecture

Non Exa Demantra Admin Utilities

8 3 Tier Architecture – Non Exa

Database, Application server, and Forecasting Engine resides on separate physical servers Recommended option for customers with Mid – Large data volume and concurrent users Majority of the customers deployed Oracle Demantra in 3 tier architecture

9 2 Tier Architecture – Non Exa

Application server and Forecasting Engine shares the same physical server. Refer system requirement document for supported OS platform for Forecasting Engine Deployment Database will reside on a separate dedicated server Suits for customers with smaller data volume ( say <= 25k Item Location Combinations) and low no of concurrent users ( <= 10)

10 Oracle Demantra Product Components

Client/s One or more client machines each running a browser to access Oracle Demantra Application server Includes web server (i.e. Apache…etc) and J2EE application server (i.e. Oracle Web logic, OAS,….etc) Demantra web application platform runs within J2EE server Metadata definitions gets loaded into Application server memory from database during startup No fact data (Sales History/Forecast) gets stored in Application server Application server clustering is not supported Database server All fact data & metadata object definitions are stored in the Demantra database schema In standard EBS VCP Integrated environment, Demantra should share database with other VCP Modules (i.e. ASCP, IO, GOP….etc) Oracle Demantra is certified to work on Oracle RAC cluster

11 Oracle Demantra Product Components Cont’d

Engine Servers One or more servers used for running analytical forecasting engine processes in both batch and adhoc simulation mode Demantra Forecasting Engine is a 32 bit application Reads the demand stream data from Database and generates statistical forecast and writes it back to the database Admin Utilities Business Modeler Consultant/Admin Tool Thick Client Used for configuring metadata object definitions to be used in the application Can be accessed from PC’s or Servers (Supported only on Windows platform) Engine Administrator Used for configuring engine settings & to enable loggings for troubleshooting Can be accessed from PC’s or Servers (Refer Oracle Demantra System Requirement document for supported platforms)

12 Oracle Demantra Supported Stacks

Refer “Oracle Demantra System Requirements” guide of relevant version to get information on latest supported stacks System requirement document for all released versions is available under Oracle Demantra documentation library (DOC ID: ) in My Oracle Support website

13 VCP Suite Implementation Requirements

To leverage standard integration between Demantra & VCP modules (ASCP, IO, GOP, APCC….etc), both Oracle Demantra and other VCP modules should be deployed on the same Database instance Above requirement is applicable for both EBS and Legacy source environment

14 Sizing Tool Overview Sizing tool is intended to enable the user to come up with a rough estimate of hardware requirements for Oracle Demantra Product and applications This includes Recommendation on range of Physical memory needed. Recommendation on range of No. of CPU Cores needed Disk Space, No of Disks and Disk controllers needed for SAN storage system These are estimates generated to best of our abilities and are provided to help the customer to anticipate the sizing needs of the application so that they can plan better. Oracle is not responsible for the inaccuracies caused by data or by the tool to come up with the estimates Sizing and the resulting architecture design should be reviewed as the project matures. Early in the project, requirements and estimates are more uncertain than they will be in later lifecycle phases, thus the hardware estimates are presented as ranges. There are many variables that can affect performance in the system used to deploy Demantra. Throughout the project lifecycle iterations of testing are required to confirm the performance suggested by the inputs, system components and user loads. Testing should use data that is a close approximation of real production data as possible. In any procurement decision, consider the range values as a proxy for system capacity. If the lower end of the range is chosen as the deployment point, make sure the system has the capacity/capability to be expanded.

15 Explanation of Sizing Inputs

16 Solution Implementing

LOV Input Possible selections are as follows DM – Demand Management CDP – Exa – Consumption Driven Planning/Oracle In Memory Demand Planning DM + Std S&OP – Demand Management and Standard S&OP DM + AFDM – Demand Management and AFDM (Promotion Modeling/Nodal Tuning) DM + AFDM + Std S&OP - Demand Management with Promotion Modeling/Nodal Tuning, and Standard S&OP DM + CTO – Demand Management with CTO DM + AFDM + CTO – Demand Management with AFDM and CTO DM + AFDM + CTO + Std S&OP – Demand Management with AFDM, CTO, and Standard S&OP solution DM + PTP – Demand Management with PTP DM + PTP + DSM – Demand Management with PTP and DSM DM + PTP + DSM + TPO – Demand Management with PTP, DSM, and TPO DM + PTP + TPO - Demand Management with PTP, and TPO DM + SPF – Demand Management with Spares Parts Forecasting (SPF) DM + CTO + SPF - Demand Management with CTO and SPF

17 Total Locations Requires either one of the following input of your supply chain depending on the lowest possible aggregation level at which you to want to load, generate, review, & manage data within the system Distinct count of “Organization/DC – Customer Ship to” relationship Distinct count of “Customer Ship to” Distinct count of “Organization/DC” One of the critical input and have significant impact on Database, Engine servers & Storage sizing

18 Total Locations - Example

Organization/DC Customer Ship to A C B 1 2 In the above example total location input could vary as follows depending on the aggregation level you plan to model Total Locations: 4 (Modeling at Organization/DC & Customer Ship to level) Total Locations: 3 (Modeling only at Organization/DC level) Total Locations: 2 (Modeling only at Customer Ship to level)

19 Total No of Finished Good Products

Requires count of Total No of Finished Good Products/SKUs that you want to plan in Oracle Demantra Account only Products/SKUs that have Independent Demand

20 Avg No of Finished Good Products per Location

In average how many no of finished good products/SKU’s sold or shipped per Location One of the critical input and have significant impact on Database, Engine servers & Storage sizing You can query relevant sales order transaction tables in the source ERP system or Data warehouse application for the last 6 months to determine this input

21 Time Bucket Base Time Bucket definition at which you plan to model the system LOV Input with following options Week Calendar Month Sub Week (available only from Demantra 12.2 onwards) Day System supports only one of the above mentioned options Week & Calendar Month time bucket definition are widely used You can choose option “Sub Week” only from Demantra version 12.2 “Sub Week” should be chosen only if you want to manage data in weekly time buckets as well as require capability to aggregate weekly data to calendar month

22 Expected Net New Products Growth % in next 5 years

Approximate Net % of new finished good products/SKU’s that you expect to introduce in next 5 years after accounting obsolete/phase out Products Following example illustrates how to compute this input Total No of Finished Good Products: 120 No of New Finished Good Products/SKU’s expected to be introduced in next 5 years: 40 No of Finished Good Products/SKU’s expected to be phased out in next 5 years: 10 Expected Net New Products Growth % in next 5 years = ((40 -10))/120) * 100 = 25

23 Expected Net New Locations Growth % in next 5 years

Approximate Net % of New Locations (i.e. New “Organization/DC - Ship to/Store” relation, Customer Ship to, Organization ) that you expect to open in next 5 years after accounting closed out Locations Following example illustrates how to compute this input Total No of Locations: 200 No of New Locations expected to be added in next 5 years: 35 No of Locations expected to be phased out in next 5 years: 25 Expected Net New Products Growth % in next 5 years = ((35 -25))/200) * 100 = 5

24 No of Years of Shipment/Booking History used for Statistical Forecasting

No of years of Shipment/Booking/Consumption History that you plan to use for Statistical Forecast generation Typical entry: 2 or 3 (Two or three years worth of history is typically used for generating statistical forecast)

25 No of years of Forecast that you plan to generate

Forecast Horizon in years Typical entry: 1 or 1.5 (One or One & Half year of forecast is typically generated)

26 Concurrent Users No of Concurrent Users during Peak Planning Cycle

No of users that you expect to use the system simultaneously during peak planning cycle One of the critical input and have significant impact on Application and Database server sizing

27 PTP/TPO/AFDM (Promotion Modeling) Sizing Inputs

Total No of Promotions per year In Average Total No of Promotions that you plan per year across all Products and Customer Locations Avg No of Products promoted together in a Promotional Event Average no of products promoted per promotional event Avg No of Locations promoted in a Promotional Event Average no of locations promoted per promotion event Avg Length of Promotions Avg Length of a Promotional Event entered in chosen "Time Bucket" definition If “Time Bucket” input is set to “Week” then enter this input in Weeks

28 PTP/TPO/AFDM (Promotion Modeling) Sizing Inputs Cont’d….

Do you anticipate to analyze Cannibalization/Halo effects Possible values: Yes or No Halo Effect - Promotion on a given products complements the sales of other related products Cannibalization - Promotion on a given products cannibalizes the sales of other related products Choose “Yes” if you plan to study these affects as part of promotions forecasting

29 Configure to Order (CTO) Sizing Inputs

No of Finished Good Products with Options Total No of Finished Good Products/SKUs which has configurable Options Avg No of Options per Finished Good Product In average, No of options offered per Finished Good Product For e.g. Finished Good Product “Laptop A” has following options and options class. Laptop A (1) Hard Disk (2) 120g (3) 200g (4) Processor (5) Pentium 2GHz (6) AMD 2GHz (7) Power Cord (Mandatory Component) (8) Total No of Options available for Laptop A: 8

30 Configure to Order (CTO) Sizing Inputs Cont’d …..

No of Years of Options Shipment/Booking History used for Planning % Calculation Typical Entry: 1 (One year of Option Shipment/Booking history will be used for calculating planning %) If you don’t plan to leverage planning % calculated based on options history then enter 0 for this input

31 Spares Parts Forecasting (SPF) Sizing Inputs

No of Finished Good Products with Spare Parts Total No of Finished Good Products which has Spare Parts No of Organizations which carries Spare Parts Total No of Organizations/DC's which carries/ships spare parts Avg No of Spare Parts per Finished Good Product Avg No of Spare Parts available per Finished Good Product Avg No of Spare Parts per Organization In average, No of Spare Parts carried by a Organization/DC

32 Consumption Driven Planning (CDP) Sizing Inputs

Total No of Retail Stores Total No of Retail Stores across all Retailers that provides Consumption (Point of Sale) and On Hand Inventory data Avg No of Finished Good Products sold per Retail Store Average No of Finished Good Products carried/sold per Store Consumption Demand Planning Time Bucket Planning Time Bucket Definition for Store level Consumption Driven Demand Planning LOV's: Day, Week.

33 Consumption Driven Planning (CDP) Sizing Inputs Cont’d

No of years of Store Consumption History will be used for Statistical Forecasting No of years of Store Consumption History that you plan to use for Statistical Forecast generation. Typical Entry: 2 No of weeks of Store Consumption Forecast that you plan to generate Store Consumption Forecast Horizon in Weeks. Typical Entry: 12 or 16 Weeks

34 Run Time Inputs Target Forecasting Engine Run Time (hrs)

Expected run time in hrs for Demantra Statistical Forecasting Engine. Demantra forecasting engine typically scheduled to run on weekends/month ends to generate statistical forecast for the entire system Consider total available time window for all the required Batch Processes relevant to Oracle Demantra including system maintenance when arriving at this input. Typical entry ranges from 4 – 12 hrs

35 Run Time Inputs Cont’d Target CTO Dependant Demand Calculation Runtime (hrs) Applicable only for CTO implementation Expected run time in hrs for running CTO Dependant Demand Batch Calculation Process. CTO Dependant Demand batch process executed after completion of Demantra statistical forecasting engine Consider total available time window for all the required Batch Processes relevant to Oracle Demantra including system maintenance when arriving at this input. Typical entry ranges from 4 – 12 hrs

36 Run Time Inputs Cont’d.. Target Spares Batch Calculation Run Time (hrs) Applicable only for SPF implementation Expected run time in hrs to derive spare parts forecast from Total Base Install & Failure Rate Target Spares Forecasting Engine Run Time (hrs) Expected run time in hrs to generate statistical forecast for spare parts

37 Run Time Inputs Cont’d Target Store Consumption Engine Run Time (hrs)

Applicable only for “CDP – Exa” implementation Defaults to 1 hr Expected run time in hrs for running Consumption Demand Stream Forecasting Engine at Retail Store level Shipment Forecast/Sell in Forecast Calculation Engine Run Time (hrs) Expected run time in hrs for running Derived Shipment Forecast/Sell in Forecast Calculation BLE Engine at DC/Retail Store

38 Run Time Inputs Cont’d…

Target Store Replenishment Order Calculation Run Time (hrs) Applicable only for “CDP – Exa” implementation Expected run time in hrs for running Suggested Store Replenishment Order calculation BLE Engine Total Available time for end to end Demantra Processes (hrs) Total time available for running all processes (Data Collection & Load, Engine Run, Maintenance, Custom Processes…etc) required for Oracle Demantra Must exceed sum of target run times entered for Forecasting engine, CTO Batch and SPF Engine & Batch. Defaults to 24 hrs if it’s not entered

39 Other Hardware Requirements – Non Exa

VM Support VMware VM is not supported. Refer Oracle Support Note for Oracle's policy on VMware VM support Oracle VM Support - From Demantra 7.3 & above Respects Oracle Database certification Respects J2EE software certification Engine Server – Only Windows Platform Database Sizing Database server sizing assumes SPARC T4-2 processors at 2.85GHz Oracle Database Enterprise Edition is strongly recommended 64 bit server is highly recommended for Application and Database server 64 bit J2EE software (Web Logic, OAS…etc) is always recommended for all solutions with an exception of TPO For TPO implementation, refer Oracle Demantra system requirement document for supported 64 bit OS platform for Application Server

40 Other Hardware Requirement – Non Exa Cont’d

Engine server sizing Assumes Intel Xeon E5540 CPU cores Required CPU Clock speed of engine servers ranges from 2.5 – 3 GHz Engine Servers can be either 32 or 64 bit For supported Windows Platform 32 bit Oracle client is required For supported Non Windows Platform 32 bit J2EE Software (Web Logic, OAS…etc) is required for Engine application deployment CPU Hyper threading should be disabled on Engine servers for better performance

41 Other Hardware Requirement – Non Exa Cont’d

Refer Oracle support note (Doc ID: ) in regards to recommended Database Best Practices for Oracle Demantra application All network equipment used to interconnect between the Demantra servers (DB, Application server, Engine server) must support at least 1Gbps. This includes network interface cards, switches and cabling. Also make sure that the storage interconnect with the DB server be fast enough and robust, so as not to be a bottleneck for data throughput

42 Sizing Request Process

Demantra Web Sizer - Self Service Tool Estimates provided are only for Production environment Web Sizer for all VCP modules are available at the knowledge in Oracle Partner Network (OPN) under VCP section Oracle registered partners can also access the sizer with their SSO credentials OPN VCP Sizer URL: Submit sizing request via web sizer tool to get hardware estimates Hardware sizing estimates will be sent to the id provided in the web sizer
